docs.snippet: Facebook offers more information about how it uses what you post on the site, at a time when it needs to exploit your data much more deftly to satisfy its would-be shareholders....
docs.abstract: Facebook offers more information about how it uses what you post on the site, at a time when it needs to exploit your data much more deftly to satisfy its would-be shareholders.

headline.main: Facebook Shares More About How It Uses Your Data

docs.snippet: The windfall from Facebook’s public offering may prompt some employees to leave, in what could be one of company’s lasting legacies — a new generation of tech tycoons looking to create or invest in, well, the next Facebook....
docs.lead_paragraph: The windfall from Facebook’s public offering may prompt some employees to leave, in what could be one of company’s lasting legacies — a new generation of tech tycoons looking to create or invest in, well, the next Facebook.
docs.abstract: Windfall from Facebook’s public offering may prompt some employees to leave, in what could be one of company’s lasting legacies--a new generation of tech tycoons looking to create or invest in their own companies, or bankroll their friends; while every public offering creates a new circle of tech magnates with money to invest, Facebook's, with a jaw-dropping $100 billion valuation, will create a far richer fraternity.

headline.seo: A Circle of Tech in Silicon Valley: Collect Payout, Do a Start-Up
headline.main: A Circle of Tech: Collect Payout, Do a Start-Up
headline.print_headline: A Circle of Tech: Collect Payout, Do a Start-Up

docs.snippet: A reader explains why Facebook’s strategy will succeed....
docs.lead_paragraph: A reader explains why Facebook’s strategy will succeed.

docs.snippet: Officials plan to enforce rules banning the publishing of any early results until all polling places close, but in an age of online media, some expressed irritation at the restrictions....
docs.lead_paragraph: Officials plan to enforce rules banning the publishing of any early results until all polling places close, but in an age of online media, some expressed irritation at the restrictions.
docs.abstract: French officials plan to enforce rules banning the publishing of any early presidential election results until all polling places close, but in the age of online media, some express irritation at the restrictions; media in Belgium and Switzerland, where public interest in French election runs high, but feelings of civic duty toward France run low, say they will publish results from districts as soon as they are available.

headline.seo: French Media Question Election Reporting Rules
headline.main: French Media Question Election Reporting Rules
headline.print_headline: French Media Question Election Reporting Rules

docs.snippet: In Tuesday's New York Times, Andrew Ross Sorkin looks at how many users Facebook really has, pointing out that the company counts as "active" users anyone who presses a "Like" button or shares a Twitter message, as well as people who go to the Web...
docs.lead_paragraph: In Tuesday's New York Times, Andrew Ross Sorkin looks at how many users Facebook really has, pointing out that the company counts as "active" users anyone who presses a "Like" button or shares a Twitter message, as well as people who go to the Web or mobile site. Read the post on DealBook»
docs.abstract: In Tuesday's New York Times, Andrew Ross Sorkin looks at how many users Facebook really has, pointing out that the company counts as "active" users anyone who presses a "Like" button or shares a Twitter message, as well as people who go to the Web or mobile site.

headline.main: DealBook: Those Millions on Facebook? Some May Not Actually Visit

docs.snippet: Facebook quickly grew from a site run from a Harvard dorm room into the Web’s largest social network....
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook quickly grew from a site run from a Harvard dorm room into the Web’s largest social network.

docs.snippet: What used to be your Facebook personal profile page will soon be known as Timeline. It will allow you to present a picture of yourself as you were once and are now....
docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone gets old. Even the clever young men who created Facebook, which is why Facebook is no longer going to be only about who you are now. It will soon allow you to curate, as they say in digi-speak, your past.
docs.abstract: What used to be your Facebook personal profile page will soon be known as Timeline. It will allow you to present a picture of yourself as you were once and are now.

docs.snippet: Facebook named Erskine B. Bowles, who recently co-chaired the Obama administration's deficit-reduction commission, as its newest board member....
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook announced on Wednesday that it had named Erskine B. Bowles, former co-chairman of the Obama administration's deficit-reduction commission, to its board.
docs.abstract: Facebook named Erskine B. Bowles, who recently co-chaired the Obama administration's deficit-reduction commission, as its newest board member.

headline.main: Facebook Adds Bowles to Its Board

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED

docs.snippet: Social media’s political sway is a given in places like the Philippines, Indonesia and Colombia, where false news often emerges to influence the vote....
docs.lead_paragraph: Social media’s political sway is a given in places like the Philippines, Indonesia and Colombia, where false news often emerges to influence the vote.
docs.abstract: Political leaders, advocacy groups and minorities worldwide demand transparency from social media networks, specifically Facebook, after several incidents in which serious misinformation was disseminated to millions of people; Facebook's role in presidential election in United States has thrown common use of social media status as primary news source into global spotlight.

headline.main: Fake News in U.S. Election? Elsewhere, That’s Nothing New
headline.print_headline: Leverage for Globe’s Gullible: Facebook’s Fake News Problem

byline.contributor: Paul Mozur reported from Hong Kong and Mark Scott from London.
byline.original: By PAUL MOZUR and MARK SCOTT
